This cover replaces the OEM cover for the fusebox on a Honda CTX700nd. I added conspicuity lighting and wired them using an add-a-circuit similar to https://www.amazon.com/Shipping-CIRCUIT-BLADE-PROFILE-FUSETAP/dp/B00K17A2E6, which raised the top of the fuses by 5mm or so. This replaces that original cover. It does not include the spare fuse holders the OEM part has.

Be sure to scan the OEM cover's sticker with the fuse chart on it, and adhere it to the top of the new cover. I used superglue to adhere and seal the paper.

author: justinds89

print_settings.Notes:: You need to print this in TPU or a flexible material.

description.text:
I got my TinyWhoop.com Race Gates and, while I LOVED the gates, the stands sucked.

So I got creative and came up with these.

I really wanted to use the fiberglass poles that came with the gates and take advantage of them since they were pretty nice poles, but I needed to do something with the clamps.

The clamps I used are "ACCO 1-1/4" Medium Binder Clips". They were what was available. I am not a clamp connoisseur, I just looked at what they had and picked these. I would think that any inch and a quarter clip would work.

I also used a 3M screw in the top to hold the clamp slot closed. I figured most guys who have quads probably had a few laying around since that is the Chinese's favorite size for Mini Quads.

The holes in the bottom of the print are for storage. One of the things that I really love about these gates is how nicely they fold up and how little room they take. I tired to do the same with my print.

This is made with TPU to allow for the clamp to flex and the poles to grip.

Hope you enjoy!
KT

UPDATE!!!
After several requests for a 2 pole version and a bit of testing I have added a 2 pole version. Has the same storage holes (very tight) in the bottom as well.

Hacked DaVinci

description.text:
I bought some kilo filament spools and wanted a wider unwind stand than the stock width that came with the ANET A8, a 130 mm strut. So here is the 160 mm strut.

The quick change spool sprocket is by jadames and you can see my make and the required hardware list here: https://www.thingiverse.com/make:442287 I made two! This with the ANET stand and the wider strut fit the Monoprice kilogram spools which are 57 mm ID, 194 mm OD, 76 mm Wide.

I did a remake using Goldie1471's foot bracket as basis for the wider strut to fit the stock ANET spool holder. It is longer and has added stress relief holes and scallops to reduce print warpage.

A two up gcode file is included in the downloads to get you going.

remixed_from.author: eburgess4
remixed_from.title: Monoprice MP Select Mini (MPSM) Tool Bracket/Holder

remixed_from.author: clayreimann
remixed_from.title: Front Mount MP Select Mini Tool Bracket

description.text:
Remixed Tool Bracket for Monoprice Select Mini.

Redesigned eburgess4's tool bracket to have tighter tolerances, Combined it with clayreimann's Tool Bracket to have only one open end to prevent tool holders from sliding all the way through, and then rounded some corners to make it less sharp and to follow the frame of the Monoprice Mini better. I am still fine tuning the filets on the corners to match the mini, so if you print it and have input please let me know. I will also likely add other tool holders as I think of things I need, If you would like to see something added let me know. If you print this out and like it, I would appreciate an "I made one".

Printer:

Monoprice Select Mini

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.13125

Infill:

50

Notes:

Print the mount on its end with the closed end down. This will minimize the supports needed and keep the channel for the tool holders clear.

The SD card and Hex holder Should be printed as it would be installed. this insures the channel for the micro SD does not warp. Support may or may not be needed to support the angled part of the holder. Best results are without supports if you can get away with it, as the key way in the bracket is a close fit and flash from the supports may make it a bit tight at first.

UPDATE: I have added a V2 version of this part that should allow for a little more clearance in the key way of the bracket itself. I have not tested this adjustment, but I reduced the size of the keyed portion of the holder by .5mm to allow a bit more room to slide in the bracket. If you print it out and it works, please let me know.

The Tape Holder I have not printed, but should be printed on its side for strength reasons. It should not require any supports. Given the amount of leverage that this will place on the keyed portion of itself, it might be a good idea to use 100% infill to prevent it snapping off.

title: Parametric cable chain with cable separators

description.text:
With the uploaded scad file you can easily create cable chains, the parameters to change are at the end of the script (line 285 and following). The file was designed for a special purpose and was not cleaned up much before upload, but hopefully it's usable for other people too :-).

length: the total length of a chain link
outerWidth: the outer width of a chain link
outerHeight: the outer height of a chain link
angle: the angle from one chain link to another
clipDiam: the diameter of the round clip that connects to links
cables: an (multidimensional) array with diameters of the cables (include additional space of 10-20% per cable). I.e.: [[7.15, 6.6, 6.6], [7.15, 7.15, 6.6], [10.8, 6.6, 4]] => creates 3 columns with each 3 cables stacked.

The wallsizes can be changed in the module "chainLink".

The switch "singleLink" in line 321 allows to switch between a usefull view for editing and export (true) and a view to see a full half circle with the chain links attached to each other in the given angle.

title: Anet A8 (Prusa i3) X-Axis 1.5mm Belt Holder

description.text:
I very much liked other designs like this however my belt was 1.5mm and would not fit them. So I redid it and optimized the belt angles and curves to make it fit in smoothly while maintaining optimal tension and print without any anomalies. Works like a charm.

I've included the Fusion 360 file to import if you need to modify it for different needs.

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.80

Infill:

100%

Notes:

You probably don't need 100% infill, but it's a small part with a lot of tension on it. It took me about 2 hours to print at these settings.

A higher resolution should allow the top chamfering to come through to allow the belt to slide in easily while remaining tight. I'd recommend running your print a little hotter than normal to maximize inter-layer bonding and there's no bridging to screw up.

When attaching the the second side of the belt, grip it with needle-nose pliers and pull it around the loop. While you want it plenty tight, if your carriage rails start sliding out of the side then you've made it way too tight and it will affect your Z-Axis in a terrible way.

title: Vive Controller Camera Mount for Mixed Reality Filming

description.text:
Camera (or other thing with 1/4" / 6mm bolt mount) mount for HTC Vive controller. I'll be using it for Mixed Reality filming, but you might have other ideas!

It grips the controller quite well when printed in ABS, but I've added space for "standard" 12mm wide velcro tape, if you're mounting your controller to a drone, or upside-down (both of which I'm doing!)

This is a work in progress, but Mixed Reality and VR are progressing quickly, and Vive Trackers will be with us soon, so I'd prefer to save people some time in the short term, rather than wait until I have a perfect design which is no longer relevant.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Notes:

I've added "ears" for better adhesion on the corners, and some supports which need to be broken off in the velcro cutout sections. Can use additional supports if desired. Should adhere fine without a raft though.
Made in Tinkercad, using the official high-res Vive Controller model. If you'd like to customize, I've shared the design for public editing

title: Relief Map of The Sutter Buttes

description.text: The Sutter Buttes are a ring of ancient volcanic domes that rise from the floor of the northern Sacramento valley. They are in the same 1 degree by 1 degree ASTER GEDEM tile as the Oroville Dam. - http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2115199 - The GEDEM data was sampled at 3 second intervals to make a relief map. The data, the fortran program that created the data, and the OpenSCAD program that calculated the relief map, are included. "ASTER GEDEM is a product of METI and NASA"

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator (5th Generation)

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 mm

According to a USGS brochure, https://pubs.usgs.gov/fs/2011/3024/fs2011-3024.pdf, Dana, who studied the Buttes in 1841, was told that they were a refuge for deer and antelope during the winter flooding of the Sacramento valley. Levee's were soon constructed; their repeated failures led to dam building and a long tiresome history of attempts to control flooding in the Sacramento valley.

Three Titan missle silos, situated near the edge of the Buttes, were once on active alert. They were retired in 1965 and have since been removed.

description.text:
Watch for a discussion on this thing in the 3D Printing Today Podcast! It's free! No ads!
threedprintingtoday.libsyn.com

After smashing into the overhead fan/lamp with my Vive controllers I realized that replacing the broken glass shade with another may not be a good idea. So instead i pulled out the digital calipers and booted up a CAD package and quickly did a copy of the shade shape. I figured i'd print one and if the wife liked it I'd leave it, if not I'd replace the whole lamp. The result looked so nice using Colofabb's XT that my wife preferred keeping it and replacing the other three shades!

The fan is a Hunter, but I'd bet the object can be scaled as needed. I used XT (PETG) given the heat from the incandescent bulb. Note that the file is rather large at 43mb! This is to ensure that there were absolutely no facets so that the shell printed nice and smooth. It could probably be decimated though.

The pic of the fan has an original glass shade on the right. 3D Printed on the left.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2mm layer height

Notes:

I set Simplify 3D with 2 processes; 1 for the lower layers with 4 shells for strength where the screws hold the shade in place, then a second with only 2 shells for translucency for the rest of the shade. I set the tops and the bottoms to "Off" and infill to zero percent. I also set the skirt distance to 0 and added 4 shells to it so there's more for the shade to hold on to the bed with.

comments.text: Headsup. My son left the lamp on for hours and the small incandescent bulbs melted the PETg. Switching to LEDs... I may redesign the shades to be much smaller too.

This project has taken several weeks to complete due to the details. Students went down to the front office and we measured everything in centimeters. We took these numbers and divided by 2 and set them to mm. This gave us a scale of 1:20.

Steps to design
  1. Students measured office objects in centimeters. For example, if a desk was 200 cm, we would divide this by 2 to get 100cm at a 1:2 scale. We would then convert to mm and it would be a 1:20 scale. 200cm -> 100mm.
  2. Students designed in Tinkercad.
CCSS
We measured each object and designed in Tinkercad. Students submitted STL files through Schoology.

This project has taken several weeks to complete due to the details. Students went down to the front office and we measured everything in centimeters. We took these numbers and divided by 2 and set them to mm. This gave us a scale of 1:20.
Students measured the items in the office and designed them in Tinkercad. My favorite item thus far is the copier!
Students were given the opportunity to design other pieces one they finished their original. We reviewed their work together. Using Tinkercad, I was able to jump on their accounts to alter any shapes that needed.
After completing the major objects in the room, we worked our way towards the desk objects.

title: OpenForge 2.0 Corner Spiral Stair Up and Down OpenLock Base

description.text:
OpenForge 2.0 and OpenLock
Still continuing upon a theme.....A roleplaying terrain feature/accessory to depict the middle of a spiral staircase going both up and down, as in a mid-floor corner tower.
Vision was a staircase tower protruding past the corner of 2 walls. As the link needs to be in the corner to properly set this up, the stairs only include a 2x2 base EB (non-standard) to link the standard tiles.

Will visit and include (here) the standard E connections only on the 2 sides of the stair entrance, as the back sides preclude that type of E connection because of the "Down" aspect of the stair tile.

Modified xloud's spiral staircase (up and down) for OpenForge to the OpenForge 2.0/OpenLock 4.0 standards. Use Devon Jones Openforge Floors and OpenForge Curved Walls to mesh together. Resized to 25.4x50.8x50.8.

Note! Printed 2/23/17 as shown.

Kudos to Printablescenery
http://www.printablescenery.com/product-category/rampage-system/
Rampage http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1821631
OpenLock 4.0 http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1833963
and DevonJones
OpenForge http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:251178
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:171315

The customizer has an invert image button. I used it. (I'm used to inverting images when making lithophanes)
1) Am I supposed to invert the image if I want it to come out normal? As I decipher my projection, it makes me think "No"

3) are you using a deposition type printer or a fancy-shmancy SLA printer? Looking at the holes at the top of the sphere, makes me think that you have an SLA printer.
You probably already answered these questions somewhere. Just point me at that and I will read up myself.
Dankeschön. -Joe

I used infill 10% but usually 20% will be better for a better final presentation. For my application 10% is just fine and with Low Quality print setting (0.15mm).

123D Design

I used 123D Design

Design software recommendation for newybies (like myself), and all.

I'm new to 3D print and 3D design. I began using Blender because I noticed it was a fave for 3D printing. Then after a few frustrations I began looking for an alternative. I found about Autodesk 123D (free for non-commercial) and gave it a try. I can do a 'thing' without expertise on 3D and the 'things' that took me ages to design on Blender take me 5 or 10 minutes on 123D. I just love it
I never wrote a review for anything but since I love this community I hardly recommend you guys to give it a try and judge it yourself. I'm sure you will love it because you'll reduce your design time a thousand percent and have excellent results.

author: TimeFramed

description.text:
This is a customizable squeeze clamp for use with an optics mounting post. Sometimes you need to hold something light in place, or just out of the way, and don't want to scratch the rod/post.

The default STL is for an 8mm post with M3 bolts and nuts.

This component was inspired by the Open-source optics project, whose goal is to radically reduce the cost of scientific optical hardware, by the Michigan Tech's Open Sustainability Technology Research Group.

OpenSCAD code included for modifications. Just print on your favorite 3D printer and clean up. For stability/strength, this part may need 25% or more infill. I have not needed supports when printing with PLA or ABS.

description.text: My first OpenSCAD creation. . . that worked when printed. Thank you Akerworks!!!

This is a customizable bolted clamp for use with an optics mounting post. Sometimes you need to hold something heavier in place, or just out of the way, and don't mind scratching the rod/post.

The default STL is for an 8mm post with M3 bolts and nuts.

This component was inspired by the Open-source optics project, whose goal is to radically reduce the cost of scientific optical hardware, by the Michigan Tech's Open Sustainability Technology Research Group.

OpenSCAD code included for modifications. Just print on your favorite 3D printer and clean up. For stability/strength, this part may need 25% or more infill. I have not needed supports when printing with PLA or ABS.
Nice, square USB and microSD holder. Has slots for 12 USB drives and 20 microSD cards. Made this one because I had no need for regular SD card holders.

description.text: Apple watch charge stand that keeps the watch in nightstand mode. Will fit both the 38 and 42 mm versions. Works well with all three bands that I own some don't fit snug around the center of the stand but this does not affect how well the stand works. The magnetic charger holds the watch firmly in place on its own. I printed the example with wood PLA at a 0.1 resolution with no support and it turned out perfectly.

remixed_from.author: Jerware
remixed_from.title: Printrbot Simple Metal RPi Camera Bed Mount

remixed_from.author: parkis
remixed_from.title: Raspberry Pi camera mount for Prusa i3

description.text:
After recently making an OctoPi to control my TAZ 6 and looking at the timelapse footage of my prints I realised I needed the camera mounted to the bed to properly see what was going on so I made this mount.

It is designed to mount on the front left corner (where the nozzle cleaner is) and fits around the auto bed levelling mount. It gets very close to the fan mounts on the extruder but does not touch them. The reason it is so close is that I built an enclosure without much y axis space and it needed it to not hit the acrylic front and this way it juuuuust fits :)

I experimented with having the camera mount rotate but always wanted the view centred on the bed anyway and it's in an easily knockable location so just fused these two parts for less complexity. In the future I may even fuse the camera mount :)

There's currently still the big hole for the external lens but it's looking like I won't put one on anyway as the camera covers the whole bed pretty well. I may remove it in the future.

I'll be uploading some pictures once I've printed one that looks nice enough to photograph and a timelapse video once I've replaced my Pi camera.

Update 1:

I wanted the camera a little higher off the bed to get a better angle on prints and I also added a channel to hold the cable along the back. I've left the original short, channel-free file up in case someone prefers the compact version but I don't plan on updating it.

I had to enlarge the channel a little as it didn't end up printing well, but on the plus side now I have a timelapse of the view from this thing as my printer prints this thing:

https://youtu.be/bhvgqYGCszA

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

TAZ 6

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

comments.text: Never mind. I found a web post describing the project in more detail. Looks like the 2 meter cable is the one needed in order to route under the bed.
comments.author: acronce

comments.text: Great camera mount. BTW, are you using LED tape lighting around the frame of your TAZ 6 and if so what brand? I am going to be doing similar lighting around the metal frame possibly in channels to keep most of the light focused on the build area and possibly adding a light and camera close to the tip of the extruder for better viewing. Thanks for sharing!
comments.author: pilotech

comments.text: Sure am, the tape is actually inserted into the aluminium extrusions :D If you are planning on doing it I'd say don't bother with the side facing the camera, it can't see what's being illuminated and just shines into the lens :) This is the strip I used on mine:

comments.text: Great, Thanks!
comments.author: tomleech

comments.text: Would there be a way for you to design a base that keeps the camera slightly closer to the bed? I have the TAZ 6 enclosure (https://printedsolid.com/products/lulzbot-taz-6-safety-enclosure-kit) and neither the small or tall mount fit in the enclosure. It's about 1" too far from the bed.

comments.text: Unfortunately, no. I am still not using my rPi camera with my printer.

comments.text: Closer in which direction?

comments.text: Sorry I didn't include that rather important detail lol. It would need to be moved closer on the horizontal plane to the corner. I.e. it can't extend as far as it currently does from the print bed. I also was curious if this would then be in the way of the extruder?
comments.author: tomleech

comments.text: Yeah, it would hit the extruder fans during auto-levelling if it were closer :(
comments.author: nate_ubiquisoft

comments.text: I'm a beginner that's been 3D printing for only a month, but I think I just uploaded a modified version of your design suggested by James at Core Electronics. I'm sure my STL is like brain surgery done by your local butcher, but it works with a little clean up and I've been printing a lot with it. As James says, the bed leveling and cleaning is 100% repeatable and this JUST fits, so I don't expect any problems. Hope this helps and Thanks for you great work. Hope I didn't butcher it too much.

author: morenot3131

description.text: A new spin on the classic Tick Tack Toe game. Print it out and challenge your friends. First one to get three in a row in any direction wins. Blog post on where the idea behind this game came from here.

I recommend printing the base at 60% infill and the Xs and Os at 10%.   
Using support material on the Xs and Os is a good idea, especially if you're using PLA and/or printing a lot of them at once. One edge that curls a little too much due to the overhang can send the whole print off.

comments.text: I made one in abs on my ToM. It required scaling the pieced to 105%, otherwise they would not fit. Took several days to print all the pieces one by one, but it is a fun game so it's worth the wait.
comments.author: pauldebra

comments.text: I'm glad you like it. Your print looks excellent.

description.text:
'X' style quadcopter frame with possibility for attachments. Made to print on small printers.
This is part of my journey into both 3D printing and 3D flying. Fun.
Designed primarily to used as a platform for robotics (computer controller flight), but aewsome fun to fly RC, it is small enough that mis-steps are not catastrophic. All parts but the electronics are printable and reprintable (I must have printed at least 9 arms!!!)

Complete (with electronics) kit available here http://bit.ly/kendoTindie

Take a look at this project on hackaday.io http://bit.ly/MinimX

title: DIY office chair cockpit for VR(HTC VIVE/OCULUS) with x52 hotas

description.text:
Space pirate trainer? Pfffttt fuck that noise, sit your ass down, fire up elite dangerous VR and live the life of a space pirate!

You'll need!
-X52
-Chair
-Filament
-3.5mm MDF board or whatever you have handy
-Scrap foam to keep a solid clamp (amount depends on thickness of chair arms)
-12 5/16th 3" - 3 1/2" hex bolts and nuts
-8 m3 10mm machine screws and nuts
-4 m4 60mm machine screws and nuts
-Misc superglue/epoxy
-3d printer (duh!)
-Dremel/handsaw/cnc/laser cutter for control plates, svgs supplied, these could possibly be 3d printed but 3.5mm MDF is super easy to cut and plenty strong enough. Lacking any automated equipment just print the svg onto payer and cut it out of mdf sheets by hand the geometry is pretty simple and wouldn't take long.

n52te not required! If you don't have or want the n52 portion don't print the additional support and just 1 more joyplate set and flip the plates before gluing together so the bolt holes line up.

My prints were done at .3mm layer height with PetG and 40% infill with 4 perimeters. Total print time was near 20 hours (due to petg and high infill) but this could be lowered to around 10 with ABS on a fast printer and slightly lower infill however you may run into issues with strength.

to do:
Currently waiting on a 81key mechanical keyboard to arrive so I can design a keyboard plate as well. As well I'll redesign the joyplate to have a small mouse pad to the side like the throttle has room for the speedpad. So it can function as a complete VR ready desk so to speak with the aid of bigscreen or virtual desktop.

description.text: I was always searching for my needle nose pliers, so I decided to make a hanger for them.  This hanger slides over the top pair of 5/16 threaded rods on a prusa.  I sized it for my mini craftsman pliers, but it should fit most mini pliers.

• Print it.
  • Clean out the holes with a 5/16 drill bit.
  • Slide it on your prusa.
  • Lose your pliers less.

I designed this to work with a Tic-Tac container, minus the white lid. It should be printed in 2 pieces, top part orientated straight up with supports. Bottom part prints laying on its back with supports for the 4 spikes but could just as easily be printed straight up and down if you put supports in the square louvers across the back.

title: QIDI X-One X End Stop (Extruder Cover Delete)

description.text: I love my QIDI X-One. It's my favorite and I've owned a Taz 5 and a Tevo Tarantula. Weight is excellent on a frame, but I dislike it on moving parts. The exrtruder cover is a heavy welded plate. If you remove it you loose the part that hits the X-End stop for homing. This fixes that. I hope in conjunction with some cooling mods to get this printers build platform to 200x160. This is the first step, but also helps improve prints by reducing the load the machine has to deal with during acceleration and increase available air to flow.

Printer:

QIDI X-One

title: Dry Box with Filament Control for Maker Ultimate

description.text:
This kit has several parts and is somewhat customized for my printer (Monoprice Maker Ultimate).

It started as a dry box for filament storage and feeding (inspired from Thomas Sanladerer's video). A little weather stripping and some silica gel in a storage bin is the foundation. The extra box clips are optional, but they give me just a little extra seal around the lid.

Adding the the hangers to the box allowed the spools to be suspended on a cheap piece of extendable curtain rod.
Update 6/11/2017: Don't bother with the curtain rod to hang the spools. It was an okay first draft solution, but it is very difficult to change spools. You basically have to remove everything and then get it remounted with the one new spool. Try this instead, Slightly Taller Spool Holder. With this you just pick up the empty spool and drop in the new one, no problem.

The little grommets for the PTFE guide tubes keep the very low friction tubes from working there their way into the box overtime and jamming the spool. Thirty (30) inches seems to be a good length for the guide tubes.

Next came the manifold to keep the several (5 in this case) tubes orderly. Note the little ring to corral the loose ends to prevent them from interfering with the print. I find a piece or two of 3M Command strips keep the assembly in place.

Finally the extruder cap keeps the guide tube upright and inline with the extruder intake to eliminate the final point of friction.

Material switching has never been easier, and all the humidity sensitive filaments almost never get exposed to the environment.

As a bonus, I've included the little camera mount for the Raspberry Pi Waveshare camera I use on my OctoPrint setup.

Purchased parts:
Curtain rod: http://a.co/dRsh3dt
Weather strip: http://a.co/6ESbD98
Eva-Dry silica box: http://a.co/4me4M0h
PTFE Tube: http://a.co/ikWlmhK
Storage bin*: https://www.walmart.com/ip/Sterilite-27-Quart-Latch-Box/46001917?wmlspartner=wlpa

  • Sorry about the WalMart link. You can get this box at Amazon, but you have to buy 6+ units.

Printer:

monoprice maker ultimate

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1 - 0..2

Infill:

20%

Notes:

The tube mount grommet will not need any infill.

The filament cap and the camera mount should be rotated -90 degrees on x-axis before slicing.

title: Dewalt Table Saw Dado Throat Plate

description.text: I bought a Dewalt 7491 Table Saw last week and have been having a blast with it. This is a dado throat plate required to install/use a dado blade. The dimensions were designed loosely off the standard Dewalt throat plate, minus the locking mechanism. I may add that at some point, but it's really not that important. Instead, I added a little piece of velcro to the inside of the opening which holds either plate in place nicely.

Printer:

Voron/Ultimaker Hybrid (DIY)

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.40

Infill:

25%

Notes:

This should print equally well with PLA or ABS, but I would recommend ABS since most people keep their saws in garage's and workshops that may not always stay cool. PLA can disfigure in relatively low heat. There's a few overhangs, but they aren't severe and should not require supports. In fact, enabling supports may interfere with the tongue and groove.

Given the dimensions, most people will need to print this as two pieces and join them. I printed mine using ABS, and joined them with a slurry of acetone and a few drops of super glue. I'm not 100% confident in the bond, so if you have better luck with something else, I'd love to hear about it. The yellow one from the pictures (an early prototype) was printed in PLA and bonded with Locktite Ultragel. So far it's held, but also feels brittle. One added benefit of the join line is that it can be used to easily find the apex of the blade.

description.text:
NOTE: I am still working on the RAMPS 1.4 config file with Marlin 1.1.0. Currently the printer does move around and extrude slowly, but not print worthy just yet.

Testing parts to upgrade my 101hero from its gear reduction steppers to actual NEMA17 steppers, with a bowden extruder.

I am calling this modification the 401sidekick.

You will need to print 3x of the NEMA mounts and 1x of the bowden extruders.

Current parts were printed on a Prusa i3 Mk2 clone, but as long as the 101hero is in working condition, I see no reason it cannot be printed on it.

Parts to keep from the original 101hero:

  • 6x M4 screws
  • 3x GT2 16T timing belt pulley w/5mm bore
  • 3x Black plastic mounts from old steppers

Parts needed not included from the original 101hero:

  • 1x M3x30 screw (or M3x32 with washers or similar to shim)
  • 12x M3x25 screws
  • 1x M3x20 screw
  • 2x M3x8 screws
  • 2x M3x6 screws
  • 19x M3 washers
  • 15x M3 nuts
  • 1x 608 bearing (608-2RS is what I am using)
  • 1x Spring
  • 1x MK7 hobbled gear (5mm shaft)
  • 4x NEMA 17 steppers (I am using 3x pancake steppers for XYZ and one full for the extruder)
  • 1x New controller board (I am using a RAMPS 1.4, no longer using the native 101hero)
  • 1x Brass PTFE push coupler
  • 1x PTFE tubing for 1.75mm filament
  • Patience!

Electronics I am using:

  • 3x NEMA 17 pancake steppers - http://www.ebay.com/itm/231619261745
  • 1x NEMA 17 (full) stepper (Had spare)
  • 4x crimp plugs and connectors(12) for stepper wiring
  • 1x RAMPS 1.4 with A4988 stepper drivers
  • 1x Full graphic LCD screen (12864) with RAMPS connector
  • 1x stock 101hero extruder (for now...)

Printer:

Prusa i3 MK2 custom

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

The NEMA mounts print with built in support for the M4 holes. These should pop out with little work.

The NEMA mounts have space for the M3 nuts, if these are too tight, warm up the nut and press fit in.

comments.text: I knew that stock extruder would be a disaster.  Already printed a bowden style and had parts on hand.  I'm going to make the swap in the next few days.  Nema17 (overkill) for the extruder and Nema14 to replaced the delta motors.

title: First Layer, Flow, Calibration, Temp, Speed, Adhesion Test

description.text:
A little on my take on the whole bed gap (bed leveling).

It can also be done hot but its just safer and easier while its cold. There is really not going to be a "set" standard on what size feeler gauge to use and even with paper everyone has a different "tension" they feel and gotten used to. You can use another's as a starting point and work from there. When the machine is cold you place a gap between your bed and the nozzle. Heat makes things expand! So your print bed and the glass will expand upwards as well as your extruder and nozzle will expand downwards. So once things are properly preheated they "should" touch. Which is what should happen because that's where the printer thinks zero is. On the bed. So when your printer moves up to say the .2mm of your initial layer height, the print head will physically be .2mm above your bed.

If you gap your bed wrong - say for a second you used .1mm to thick of a method - Now when everything preheats and expands, the print head is no longer on the bed, its now .1mm above the bed. Now when it moves up to your initial layer height of .2mm your first layer will actually be .3mm The printer will still print this but it will only extrude .2mm worth of material for the .2mm gap that's programmed. This will result in a bad layer contact with the bed which equals poor adhesion, prints lifting off the bed, warping, prints completely popping off mid print.

If the bed is gapped too close to the bed the nozzle can scrape the bed on the first layer and damage the print bed or the nozzle. Issues with back pressure as its trying to push out more filament than the gap that's available - This can also result in filament grinding which causes the extruder gear to fill up with filament - become smooth and cause print issues by slipping. Also excessive clogging

I added a few different layer thicknesses just in case you cant scale them.

As a first layer, It should make only one pass. It should also measure the same thickness as the initial layer height you have set in your slice. If they do not measure the same you need to adjust how you gap your bed.

If you really want to get crazy, scale it to the width and depth of your entire print surface! Measure to know how far off your first layer is to the actual settings are to your slicer settings.

You can also do a thicker test, in witch you could see if there's a difference between the layers as well as a how your top layer looks.

Layers should be smooth and all lines connected to appear to be a completely smooth skin. As you try printing faster, you might notice like its not laying enough material/ lines are thinning, so increase temp to properly melt the filament.

Or the lines are overlapping on one side and have gaps on the other, then you probably have mechanical issues within the printer, belt or alignments.

How to gap the bed with my Monoprice Maker Select v2.1. While the machine is cold and the tip of the nozzle is clean - just metal, no plastic hanging down. I use a piece of paper between the nozzle and check the 4 corners of the bed. Once I can feel a little drag from the nozzle pressing on the paper between the bed, I continue around the bed. I personally find it easiest to get 1 edge first, then move around the bed. The first time may take a bit as when you adjust one corner then another, the previous will become loose or tighter. This will become second nature and much faster the more you do it. Repeat this process until all corners are the same and no longer need adjustment.

Why is there is no set standard in what gauge thickness to use?
Because nobody is really using the same setup. Stainless nozzles, borosilicate glass, window glass, buildtack, pei, ect, ect, ect. These all have different thermal expansions and in so will require a different gauge thickness. On top of the temp used which will cause more/less expansion.

Granted - most of the time, close is good enough. But if you have ever wondered why someone else's thickness doesn't work for you. Now you know.

A game for the tots to learn many skills including memorization, concentration, association.

The design is made to use .125 material. I used Baltic Birch. Simply cut the design out, glue up the storage box and you are ready to go. 
1) Set your laser to color map so that red is an engraving and black is a complete cut.
2) Glue up the box. I find the easiest way to do this is the interlock the sides with the bottom laid out flat and run a thin bead of glue along the joint and then fold up the sides. I then use a small dry brush, such as an acid brush, to remove any extra glue.
3) Glue up the box cover in much the same fashion as the bottom. 
To play the game:
Turn all pieces upside down on the playing field (floor, coffee table, etc.) Each player takes turns flipping over two pieces. If the pieces do not match, they are returned to the upside down position and the next player takes their turn. If the pair is a match, the person removes the two tiles from the field and sets them aside. When all the pieces are removed from the playing field, the person with the most tiles wins.

description.text:
This is a diffuser for the 12 LED Adafruit NeoPixel. It is specifically made to press fit on top of the Adafruit NeoPixel Ring 12 Leds Fitting - http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:424381

For my application (light painting) I am setting all the pixels to the same color and want to create a single color diffused light. Printed in a clear PLA filament that comes out a clear, whitish color. I used some sandpaper to rough up the outside and inside of the circular top. I've also added a few layers of wax paper inside to help out.

The original file is about 7mm tall and had the "lens" too close to the pixels. The v2 file is about 23mm tall and does a much better job.

The second half of my play kitchen.  The faucet that came on the kitchen was really lame.  I don't know whether there was something missing or it really was that bad straight out of the box.  
Either way, I made a replacement faucet, and like the stove in part 1, this is designed to be universal, so you can make a kitchen out of anything - EVEN CARDBOARD!  
The knobs both turn and so does the spout.

Print a hot and cold handle as well as a spout.  The base is optional.  
Then drill out the pilot holes for whatever size screw you're using and assemble.  
Appropriate backs are included in all models.

description.text: This is an assortment of basic pegboard hooks. There are two variations (round and straight) with three sizes of each (10 mm, 15 mm, and 30 mm). Both of the 10 mm hooks are significantly thinner than the others in order to accommodate items with smaller holes. The straight versions are angled upwards at 30 degrees.

Printer:

M3D Micro

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.35 mm

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Tested with PLA on an M3D Micro using the lowest quality setting (0.35 mm) and 4 walls. The parts are small and thin enough that the infill setting shouldn't matter much.
If the bottom peg is tight, sand it down lightly with sandpaper until you achieve the desired fit.

These hooks are based on CycleNinja's pegboard hook (for the lower peg) and Nightcrispy's modified version (for the upper peg). The shapes of the hooks are loosely based on commonly available metal pegboard hooks. The source SketchUp file (containing all hook variations and sizes) is also included.

title: Scalpel case
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
This is the scalpel carrying and storage case we've been working on for some time now. The idea is to create a case able to hold one, three or five scalpels safely. It must be safe and hold the scalpels securely enough to put in a bag or pocket without it opening or breaking.

We tested this with different scalpels and blades. It will fit most scalpels, Swann-Morton no 3, and a bunch of unbranded ones. A version for Swann-Morton no 4 or for other types will be uploaded upon request.

Be sure your print has good layer adhesion and is strong enough for the forces it has to withstand before tossing it in a bag or somewhere it might hurt someone if broken. Scalpels are designed to cut flesh, so be careful.

The big logo on top of the cases visible in the animated gif has been replaced with a smaller more discrete one, on the sides of the cases.

This is the result of our scalpel tray study, http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2099632

We are already deep into development of version two, which is possibly going to be thing no: 2380454.

This thing is designed to be printed with both parts standing up. Clean of the small supports underneath the pivot points and gently snap together.

Also, this thing will probably never be sterile. But if you (for a second) wanted it to be for some reason, you probably already knew that.

title: DOMETIC toilet tank cap
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Yesterday it happened: while draining my motorhome's Dometic toilet tank, the cap slipped out of my hand, and disappeared in the drain ... Bummer. :(
In stores these things go for 20 euro and more, so time for some DIY'ing ! :)

Since this cap has a 6mm pitch buttress thread, it has to be printed open end down to avoid overhang and support issues. A 2 part breakaway support is already in the design, so no support is needed.
Finish off with a bead of silicone, an O-ring or other type of end seal.
If you can improve on this, please do so, let me know, and share !

Dometic partnumber seems to be 2426014888.
Replaces caps for models CT, CTLP, CTS and CTW 4050/4110

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/5haWOGZzCvI

title: Tevo Black Widow - original Control box

description.text:
I recreated the control box parts of the Tevo Black Widow 3d printer to help you designers design upgrades/attachments for the printer or just print replacement parts for when the acrylic breaks. Everything should be to scale.

Update:
I added a version of the long parts that can be printed on smaller printers like the Tevo Tarantula with a 200x200mm bed. The parts can be glued together for a extra strong bond since the dovetail bond can be to weak on its own. There is a 0.2mm gap between the connections which should be enough to make it fit, if not just sand down the edges until it fits.

Created by Roel Versteeg
Feeling generous? Feel free to tip me, this helps covering the costs of waisted prototyping fillament and time spend designing.

THere is 2 models for the front support. I printed the one with a slide for the feets and definitively, it's the best!

There is place for every cable and the vents are keep clear.

I maked holes to put a screw but check the size! I have very special screw and screwdriver so it work, but just for me I think!

As the model is provided, you could modify it for your needs.
Please !! Send me a pic if you made it !

remixed_from.title: Anet A8 Specific Y-Axis Carriage Plate Upgrade

title: Anet A8 Y-Carriage upgrade
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Like http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2063292 this is an upgrade to the Anet y-carriage with clearance for the y-axis motor and more stiffness than the original part delivered.
Outer dimensions are 219x219mm so should fit every printer with a similar design like Anet A6 etc.
I removed the option to mount only three bearings since the original P3Steel evolved in removing this option, so why would one add it again?
Since the distance of the holes on the P3Steel and the Anet for mounting the bearings and y-belt are different, i added mounting holes and cutouts for the original P3Steel parts.
All holes are designed as clearance holes.

update 17-03-02: received the frame today and will install it later. Be advised that you have to modify the y-endstop if you decide to not take the original bearings with their housing and you have to check if your y-belt tensioner does interfere with the carriage. If so, you have to print another tensioner before installing.

comments.text:
I don't have access to edit DXF files - but a carriage for a heated bed of size 300x300 (for a custom built printer based on A8 principles, but controller by RAMPS) is what I am looking for. Heated bed mounting hole details on http://www.reprap.me/reprap-alu-heatbed-mk3-300x300mm.html
I am not sure about the location of the SC8UU bearings - if they should be in the same place (distance to edge), or maybe a bit more centered..
Are you able to create a customized version and make a picture available ? Then I can try to see if it what I had in mind.

description.text: Jonjb2a: Created using original designs

This is a remix of this thing, https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1398528 which provides some barndoors to the LED Luxpad22.

I had the problem, that my building platform was simply to small for the original frame which holds the barn doors. So I made a version consiting of four edges which hold the barns. When the doors are screwed to the edges, with M3 screws, everything fits very nice to the Luxpad. In addition to the original design you got a barndoor for the bottom as well, while you sitll can mount the Luxpad. I also reworked the shape of the doors, also the hinges are now fix on the door itself.

I pinted the doors upside down, with the hinges up, without any support structure.

print_settings.Notes:: Printed with PETG for safety. It is better to place shaft towards table and have supports around. This improves quality of shaft as it does not get too hot between layers.

title: AEG Favorit dishwasher water circulation pump wheel

description.text:
Hi,

Here's wheel for dishwasher water circulation pump. It fits for ACC EB085d25/2t pump.

AEG p/n: 1113196008 replaces: 1110996905

Printed on PETG with 100% infill and 0.2mm layer. printed slowly 800mm/min for good adhession and surface quality.

No need to make thread on wheel, just turn it until the end of wheel tube touches plastic flange on motor shaft.

Unplug from mains!! For easy access turn washer on floor, left side down. Bottom plastic plate can be removed, it has few locking levers. Drain all water out first.

Few points to take care:

Test fit plastic flange on motor shaft into wheel's shaft. Should fit in nicely, sand wheel shaft if necessary. There is section on motor shaft without thread, before flange surface, check that hole on wheel shaft is not too tight, use drill bit to make clearance on hole if necessary.

Once wheel is tightened on shaft, check that spring loaded plastic seal is pushing properly against seal surface on housing flange. If not, do not over tighten, but shorten shaft on wheel.

Run couple sets of dishes side cover open to see if there is some leaks.

Printer:

CTC 3D

Yes

Notes:

Printed with PETG for safety. It is better to place shaft towards table and have supports around. This improves quality of shaft as it does not get too hot between layers.

remixed_from.title: Case for E010 with camera and antenna guard

title: Tiny Whoop E010 case with tray

description.text:
Remix of the excellent case by ByteSlinger.

I added a middle tray for more batteries, resized the lid to suit my lower TW (whip antenna)

Tray will be a very tight fit, and most likely need a little sanding on the outer edges before it will fit in position. You can sand it to get as tight or loose fit as needed.
(I just used some 400grit paper and spent ten minutes sanding, fitting etc.)
I had the 5 pack charger that comes with the 45c E010 batteries from Banggood (very good batteries! ) I cut down the wires, resoldered them for less mess, then taped to the inside of the lid as a charging tray. Works well.

Printed in PLA (Excelvan green).
0.2 layes, takes about 7 hours for the base (!) , 6 for the lid and about 2 or so for the tray.
Quite a long print but the original design of this case is a really nice and chunky., feels good when done.

Picture of the black case, - the black lid is one I redesigned to have a lower height - it cant fit the charger in the lid space. But prints quicker!
No file for it at the moment though.

remixed_from.author: aubenc
remixed_from.title: 1024:1 planetary gear set derived from "Tiny Planetary Gears Set"

title: 1,048,576:1 Planetary gear set derived from "Tiny Planetary Gears Set" by aubenc

description.text:
I was very impressed by the "Tiny Planetary Gears Set" by aubenc but had trouble with the long screws so have redesigned the connecting system.
My design uses D section rods which are printed lying down, and spacers to position the ring gears correctly. More parts to print, but easier to print and easier to assemble.
The ring gear has been modified to accept the D section rods.
I've also modified the design of the crank - I've used a left hand thread so the handle tends to self tighten when the crank is turned clockwise (with the crank nearest you and the gear set pointing away from you).
Note that this design requires the sun and planetary gears, and the planet holder from "Tiny Planetary Gears Set" http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:23030
A couple of weeks ago I posted http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:204809 which also used parts from "Tiny Planetary Gears Set" but at 2X scale. The 1x scale parts are close to the limits of what is sensible on my equipment and required quite a bit of post print trimming etc.
I've been trying to think of a way to show the gearbox working, that is to see movement at the output end. At the moment I'm rather at a loss. I calculate that if I wanted to observe the output moving one tooth pitch (1/9th of a revolution), and drove the input at 350 RPM (slow speed on my cordless drill) it would take over 5 hours! Suspect that the drill would lose charge and the gear box would overheat and seize up.

The D section rods should be printed lying down, and the spacers standing vertically.
I recommend making one set of sun, planetary and ring gears together with one planetary holder and one rod to check fits and clearance before starting 'mass production'.
The D section rods should be a close sliding fit through the ring gears (once the parts have had excess material removed after printing).
This helps to keep the frame pretty rigid. The spacers should be a freely sliding fit.
The planetary gears sun gear from "Tiny Planetary Gears Set" I cleaned with a 3.2mm drill.
When assembling the gear set I suggest pre-assembling a ring gear/sun gear/planetary-gears-and-holder sub-assembly and sliding the sub-assembly onto the D section rods as one unit.
Because of the large number of components you may find it necessary to make some custom 'z' scaled spacers to get the end plate close to the tapered pins.

comments.text: Are the solid files available for this by chance?  STEP preferred.
comments.author: discojon

comments.text: I have no access to the gear files you'd have to approach aubenc for those.
comments.author: discojon

comments.text:
This was before I got in the habit of stating what material I used, and the supplier.
I can be certain that it was PLA because I did not have the capability of using ABS. However I can't tell you the supplier, though it may well have been Diamond Age.
PLA is pretty brittle. Some colours have the side effect of reducing brittleness to some extent so it may be worth your while trying a different colour.
If you can't solve with colour change, or perhaps a higher extrusion temperature, then I'd recommend Polymaker's PolyMax PLA which is significantly less brittle than regular PLA. - and prints very well!

comments.text: I've posted an extremely boring video showing the movement of the pointer by making a clip from 21 stills shot 100 turns of input apart: http://youtu.be/tc6ZZ3E_38Yhttp://youtu.be/tc6ZZ3E_38Y
comments.author: mgg942

comments.text:
I've thought of a less elegant method - but one more suited to my capabilities. I've designed and printed a 180mm radius pointer and a hub on which to mount it. stl files posted.
Then I mounted the gear set in a vice and photographed the end of the pointer against a reference, then turned the input crank 100 times and took another photo, and repeated this 20 times. A posted photo shows the crude set up and the distance the pointer moved after 2,000 turns. This is a pretty crude system, but taking the 2.6mm at face value the gear set ratio calculates to close to 900,000:1. Pretty close, I reckon.
comments.author: mgg942

comments.text:
To observe the output shaft turning you may want to try this:
attach a small mirror and shine a laser pointer on it.
The reflected spot on a distant wall shoud move visibly.

Supports:

No

One of the best way to hang your headphones to the Desktop with style. For better quality, you could print all 4 pieces at once. After you printed all the pieces, trim away the support material from the knob and make it look like in the picture.

To keep it from slipping away, I also added two leather or rubber pads of 40x8 mm. The leather sims to be working better and I glued the pads to the plastic jaws using cyanoarilate quick glue (or super glue).

You will also need some nuts and bolts for the joints as follows:

  • 2pcs M3 nut
  • 2pcs M3x35mm bolt
  • 1pcs M4 nut
  • 1pcs M4x60mm bolt

  • (optional )4pcs M4 washer for smooth turning of the knob (place 3pcs under the knob and 1pcs under the bolt head on the other side of the gripper)

    I used a soldering iron to heat the nuts and to immerse them in to their hexagonal holes.

    Hint: It helps the knob turning movement if you lubricate the M4x60mm bolt with a drop of mineral oil.

    Have fun recreating this project and post your pictures.

title: Coffee Jar adaptor for Water Pipe

description.text:
OG Bong adaptor for using a recycled coffee jar, pvc pipe and some garden hose.

Version 1.0.2 (the hose hole has been increased slightly to make fitting the hose easier)

Materials:
50g Moccona Coffee Jar (Australia and NZ)
160mm of Garden Hose (Approx 13-14mm)
300mm of 32mm pvc pipe (approx 36mm outside dia).

Remove the rubber attachment on the original jar lid and place on the adaptor.
Folding the garden hose in half length ways helps with fitting the hose.
I used sticks in the hose while twisting it to remove the fold once in place.
The PVC Pipe fit nicely for me, but i also covered the joint with a short length of bicycle inner tube.

author: Phil_Maddox

title: Replacement part for Neff/Siemens Fridge door

description.text:
The door of my fridge was falling apart and I discovered it was because of a broken plastic part.
I could have ordered one, but hey, a 3d printer is also there to solve every day problems...
So I designed the piece, printed and voila, fridge fixed.

This is for a Neff fridge, but apparently Siemens also use the same (maybe even more brands ?)

Sketchup file is provided so you can easily edit if needed.

I recommend printing on the side (even if that requires support) because the layers will be oriented in a much stronger way.
You should also use ABS and give the part a quick acetone bath after the print.

If you apply both, you will get a part as strong as the original.

comments.text:
Partnumber is 00169301.
http://www.siemens-home.bsh-group.com/de/shop-produktliste/00169301
In Germany it is €3,05 plus €4,70 shipping cost.

This bird and birdhouse set makes a handy place to store your keys. The bird works as a safety whistle when it is held with fingers blocking both the eyes. The bird can also be filled with water to make some delightfully loud chirping sounds. Try filling it with soapy water to have bubbles come out of the eyes!
Thread a 1" diameter (or similar) key ring through the bottom of the bird and hang the birdhouse with one screw, two screws, or double sided tape.

Depending on material used and print settings, the bottom of the bird may not be water tight. Experiments with pausing the print when the bottom is accessible and adding some dabs of silicone sealant are warranted. UPDATE Feb 2017 - "crusoe" on Reddit recommends using PVC glue to seal the bottom of the bird

title: Wooden Farm Fence replacement for Wooden Farm Set

description.text:
This is a replacement part for the Wooden Farm Set of my kid (see the picture for the original set and the original fence). He lost one so I measured and designed an exact copy.

You can print the entire thing pre-assembled, but that gave me a little hang on the horizontal bars. So I also designed the parts separate and you can just plug them together. If you want to be sure that your kid cannot get it loose just put a little glue in the holes before attaching the bars on the pilars.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator Mini+

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0,20mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Printing the fully assembled fence gave me a little hang on the horizontal fence-bars.
My best result was by printing the parts separately and then joining them together by pushing the bars in the pilar-holes. If you want to be sure it won't get loose you can just put a little glue in the hole before attaching them.

On my makerbot the best result for the bars was when I printed them vertically (as in the design file).
Let the kids start playing!

title: Wanhao i3 extruder plate for flex plastics

description.text:
This is an extruder plate for wanhao i3 duplicator (and probably printers with the same extruder). This plate has much narrower gaps to the feeder gear and to the extruder itself, thus allowing to apply more pressure on flexible filaments.
Works with rigid filaments too, plus it makes it easier to install a new filament.

Printed with PLA at 0.15 height, on i3 itself (with the stock plate). It does not melt or overheat as the extruder metal bar does not get too hot.

You might need to retrace the filament hole with a drill, but for me it printed fine.

A model of a traditional Maramureș gate, commonly found in Romania. This was a gift for our association originally.
Onshape

This is my second draft of a customizable polyhedron connector generator in OpenSCAD. I first modeled these in Inventor (see screenshot of tetrahedron connectors made for 1/4" wood dowels). Now this has been generalized into a parametric model in OpenSCAD. At present, the code creates connectors for the 5 platonic solids, the Rhombic Triacontahedron, as well as regular right prisms with adjustable base polygon order. A number of dimensions can be modified (length, internal and external diameter, base height, hole shape, hole depth, edge fillet radius, expansion slot dimensions, and base height).

Next in the queue is to incorporate options to create polyhedron connectors for Antiprisms, and a rhombic dodecaderon. The Archimedian solids, are also on the list, but are a bit more challenging.

***Note this is still a work in progress and will likely evolve as more shapes are coded in.

The option for selecting vertex number currently only matters with the Rhombic Triacontahedron, as it has 5-way and a 3-way connector. Vertex number will come into play when other polyhedra with multiple vertex connectors are coded.

Tolerance Gap also does not function yet. Stay tuned!

play with the other features and see what you can make! Any suggestions or requests?
